msDesc.head: Homilies; England (Worcester), s. xiimed; s. xiii1

msContents.summary: Homiliary begun in the second quarter of the twelfth century (1140s?). Begins with a unique homily on St Chad (pp. 1-18). Fols 18-152, 179-252, 279-90 are homilies for 24 June to 30 November, from Ælfric's First Series of Sermones catholici. Pages 253-78, 290-395 are catechetical and mainly Ælfrician, and most also occur in MS. Hatton 115. The Tremulous Hand adds glosses in Latin and English.

msItem.title: Anonymous Homilies, Homilies for Specified Occasions, Sanctorale: Saint Chad (Cameron B.3.3.3)
msItem.rubric: (1r/2) IN NATALE SANCTI CEADDE EPISCOPI. ˥ CONFESSORIS
msItem.incipit: MEN þa leofestan. ic eow onginnu secgan
msItem.explicit: se leofað ˥ rixað mid þam feder ˥ mid þam haligan gasta in eallre worulda woruld. AMEN.

msItem.author: Ælfric
msItem.title: First Series of Homilies [Catholic Homilies I]: John the Baptist (Cameron B.1.1.27)
msItem.incipit: SE GODSPELLERE LUCAS awrat on cristes béc
msItem.explicit: þam sy wuldor ˥ lof mid fæder ˥ mid halgum gaste a on ecnesse. AMEN.

msItem.author: Ælfric
msItem.title: First Series of Homilies [Catholic Homilies I]: Peter and Paul (Cameron B.1.1.28)
msItem.incipit: Venit iesus in partes cęsarere philippi. Et reliqua. MATHEVS. se godspellere awrat on þæra godspellican gesetnesse
msItem.explicit: þæt him ne bið getiþod naþor ne synna forgifenes. ne infær þæs heofonlican rices

msItem.author: Ælfric
msItem.title: First Series of Homilies [Catholic Homilies I]: Passion of Peter and Paul (Cameron B.1.1.28.1)
msItem.rubric: De passione beatorum apostolorum Petri. ˥ pauli.
msItem.incipit: WE willað æfter þisum godspelle eow gereccan
msItem.explicit: þurh þes hælendes tiðe. þam si wuldor ˥ lof. a on ecnesse AMEN

msItem.author: Ælfric
msItem.title: First Series of Homilies [Catholic Homilies I]: Paul (Cameron B.1.1.29)
msItem.incipit: GODES gelaþung wurðaþ þysne dæg
msItem.explicit: þæt hi mid him ˥ mid gode þæt ece lif habban moton. AMEN

msItem.author: Ælfric
msItem.title: First Series of Homilies [Catholic Homilies I]: Laurence (Cameron B.1.1.31)
msItem.incipit: ON DECIES dagum þes welhreowan caseres
msItem.explicit: he þrowode mid cenum mode mænifealde tintregu. mid þam he orsorhlice on ecnesse wuldraþ. AMEN

msItem.author: Ælfric
msItem.title: First Series of Homilies [Catholic Homilies I]: Assumption of the Virgin (Cameron B.1.1.32)
msItem.incipit: Heironimus se halga sacerd awrat ænne pistol
msItem.explicit: Se þe leofað ˥ rixað mid fæder ˥ halgum gasta on ealra worulda woruld. AMEN

msItem.author: Ælfric
msItem.title: First Series of Homilies [Catholic Homilies I]: Bartholomew (Cameron B.1.1.33)
msItem.incipit: Wyrdwriteras secgað þæt þry leodscipas synd gehatene india
msItem.explicit: Sy him wuldor ˥ lof on ealra worulda woruld. AMEN

msItem.author: Ælfric
msItem.title: First Series of Homilies [Catholic Homilies I]: Decollation of St John the Baptist (Cameron B.1.1.34)
msItem.incipit: Misit herodes et tenuit iohannem. ET RELIQVA. MARCVS se godspellere awrat on cristes bec
msItem.explicit: Se þe leofað ˥ rixað mid feder ˥ mid halguum gaste áá butan ende. AMEN

msItem.author: Ælfric
msItem.title: Remaining Homilies by Ælfric: Homily for the Nativity of the Blessed Virgin [first part] (Cameron B.1.5.8)
msItem.incipit: MEN þa leofostan. we synd gemungode
msItem.explicit: ˥ hire deopnesse on diglum andgite underniman willað on incundre heortan

msItem.author: Ælfric
msItem.title: Remaining Homilies by Ælfric: Homily for the Nativity of the Blessed Virgin [second part] (Cameron B.1.5.8)
msItem.incipit: SE halga hælend crist. ˥ se heofonlica æþeling
msItem.explicit: þam is wuldor ˥ wurðmynt a to worulde. AMEN

msItem.author: Ælfric
msItem.title: First Series of Homilies [Catholic Homilies I]: Dedicatio ecclesiae sancti Michaelis (Cameron B.1.1.36)
msItem.incipit: MANEGVM is cúð se hálige stow sancte michaeles
msItem.explicit: se þe leofað ˥ rixaþ á on ecnesse. AMEN

msItem.author: Ælfric
msItem.title: First Series of Homilies [Catholic Homilies I]: All Saints (Cameron B.1.1.38)
msItem.incipit: HALIGE lareowas ræddon þæt se geleaffulle gelaþung
msItem.explicit: mid fæder. ˥ mid halgum gaste. áá on ecnesse. AMEN

msItem.author: Ælfric
msItem.title: First Series of Homilies [Catholic Homilies I]: Clement (Cameron B.1.1.39)
msItem.incipit: MEN ÐA leofestan. eower geleafa biþ þe trumra
msItem.explicit: se þe leofað ˥ rixaþ a butan ende. AMEN

msItem.author: Ælfric
msItem.title: First Series of Homilies [Catholic Homilies I]: Andrew (Cameron B.1.1.40)
msItem.incipit: Ambulans iesus iuxta mare galileę. ET RELIQVA. Crist on sumere tide ferde wið þære galileiscan sǽ
msItem.explicit: Sy þam ælmihtigan drihtne wurðmynt. ˥ lof á on ecnesse. AMEN.
msItem.note: The present quire XII (pp. 253-278) originally came after the present quire XIII (pp. pp. 279-94)

msItem.author: Ælfric
msItem.title: Remaining Homilies by Ælfric: Homily for the Common of a Confessor (Cameron B.1.5.11)
msItem.incipit: Vigilate ergo. MATHEVS se godspellere us sæde on þysum godspelle.
msItem.explicit: þe ealle þing gescop. se þe ana rixað on ecnesse. AMEN

msItem.author: Ælfric
msItem.title: Remaining Homilies by Ælfric: Hexameron (Cameron B.1.5.13)
msItem.rubric: De Exameron; þæt is. BE GODES SIX DAGA weorcum.
msItem.incipit: ON sumum oðrum spelle we sædon hwilon ǽr
msItem.explicit: on anre godcundnesse. ána soð scyppend eallra. 'þinga' AMEN

msItem.author: Ælfric
msItem.title: Tracts: Interrogationes Sigewulfi in Genesin (Cameron B.1.6.1)
msItem.incipit: SVM geþungen lareaw wæs on engla lande albinus gehaten
msItem.explicit: þam is anwurðmynt mid þam halgan gaste on ealra worulda woruld. we cweðaþ AMEN

msItem.author: Ælfric
msItem.title: Tracts: De Duodecim Abusivis (Cameron B.1.6.2)
msItem.rubric: DE OCTO UITIIS ET DE XIIcim. ABVSIVIS.
msItem.incipit: OMNIA nimia nocent et temmperantia mater uirtutum dicitur. Þæt is on englisc. Ealle oferdone þing deriað
msItem.explicit: Si him ǽ wuldor ˥ wurðmynt. AMEN

msItem.author: Ælfric
msItem.title: Third Series of Homilies [Lives of Saints]: On Augeries (Cameron B.1.3.18)
msItem.incipit: SE APOSTOL paulus ealra þeoda lareow manode þa cristenan
msItem.explicit: mid him æfre to wuni'g'enne on þam ecum witum a buton ende

msItem.author: Ælfric
msItem.title: Homilies of Ælfric: De Falsis Diis (Cameron B.1.4.22)
msItem.incipit: O FRATRES dilectissimi diuina scriptura
(365/13) EAla ge gebroðra þa leofestan. þæt godcunde gewrit us tæhte
msItem.explicit: Þam si wuldor ˥ lof a to worulde AMEN

msItem.author: Ælfric
msItem.title: Tracts: De Septiformi Spiritu [Be þam halgan gaste] (Cameron B.1.6.3)
msItem.incipit: Spiritus sanctus pro septenaria operatione
(374/9) Þæt ilce on englisc. ISAIAS se witega awrát on his witegunge. be þam halgum gaste. ˥ be his seofonfealdum gifum
msItem.explicit: him godes gast on wunige oððe þæs gramlican deofles

msItem.author: Ælfric
msItem.title: Letter to Brother Edward (Cameron B.6.2)
msItem.incipit: Her geswultelað on þisum gewrite. hu god ælmihtig forbead mancynne ælces cynnes blod to etenne
msItem.explicit: hit bið swa þeah to astorfenum geteald

listBibl.bibl: M. Clayton, 'Letter to Brother Edward: A Student Edition,' Old English Newsletter, vol. 40, no. 3 (Spring 2007), 31-46.

msItem.title: Anonymous Homilies [for unspecified occasions, published]: Napier 1888, 154: 'De infantibus non baptizandis' (Cameron B.3.4.51)
msItem.incipit: WE biddaþ eow men ˥ beodaþ on godes naman
msItem.explicit: ˥ hæfð þonne hellewite gif hit hæþen acwylð

msItem.title: Anonymous Homilies [for unspecified occasions, published]: Napier 1888, 155: 'De cognitatione' (Cameron B.3.4.52)
msItem.incipit: SE swicola deofol þe syrwð ymbe mancynn asent yfele geþohtas
msItem.explicit: swa he lufode forþam þe crist agylt ælcum be his dædæ

msItem.title: Anonymous Homilies, Homilies for Specified Occasions, Temporale: In Letania Maiore (Cameron B.3.2.33)
msItem.incipit: MEN þa leofestan þis sinden dagas mid eallum cristnum folce
msItem.explicit: se þe leofað ˥ rixað mid suna ˥ mid þam halgan gaste á butan æghwylcum ende. AMEN.

msItem.title: Collect and antiphon for Saint Catherine's Day (25 November)
msItem.incipit: Deus qui dedisti legem moisi
msItem.note: Added in a later 12th century hand

msItem.title: Latin-English Glossary
msItem.incipit: ceac. vrceus... iþingþe meritum
msItem.note: Attributed to the 'tremulous hand of Worcester'

msItem.title: Single line of Middle English Verse
msItem.incipit: ic am nout for þisse þingc wo

supportDesc.support: Pages i-vi, 403-8 are paper leaves of the date of binding. Pages 399-402 are parchment end-leaves taken over from the medieval binding .
supportDesc.foliation: Paginated i-vi, 1-84, 84a, b, 85-160, 160a, b, 161-408. Another pagination, 1-396, of s. xvi(?), is on rectos only.
supportDesc.collation: 1-1012, 11-128 (pp. 237-52, 279-94), 1312 + one leaf before 1 (pp. 253-78), 1414, 15-1612, 178, 1810 wants 7-10, probably blank, after p. 398. Quire 12 (pp. 279-94) has been bound wrongly after Quire 13 (pp. 253-78).

layoutDesc.layout: 20 long lines (21 on pp. 255-78, 295-395) with blind-ruled double bounding lines. Pages 96-8 are blank, except for scribbles in the Tremulous Hand and some musical notes.

handNote.p: Pages 1-395: 'A handsome, round, large hand of a type found commonly in West of England manuscripts of s. xii' (Ker 1957, p. 406). This Worcester hand is rounded, but degrees of angularity are also creeping in. The general aspect is slightly backward-leaning. The bodies of the letters are large in relation to the ascenders and descenders. The manuscript is blind-ruled. Worcester manuscripts (which this is) are crayon-ruled from about the 1130s and 40s. Treharne (2000) dates this hand and manuscript to s. xii2/4 (pp. 25-26). That dating is re-confirmed here, probably closer to the middle of the century than earlier, even though the ruling is blind. Palaeographical affinities can be found with the Worcester manuscripts, Worcester Cathedral Libary F. 82 and F. 83, both datable to s. xiimed. Small extracts of these manuscripts appear in Thomson 2001 (pl. 42 (a)-(f)). See Ker 1957, p. 406; Treharne 2000, pp. 25-26

p.seg: a is Caroline, where the bow sometimes touches the preceding letter.
The e of æ is very slightly taller than the top of a.
Insular, rounded d is used in English, but with relatively high back, slightly shorter than that of ð; straight-backed d with an oblique serif to the right is used in Latin.
f is Caroline and sits on the line, with the mid-stroke often touching the following letter in ligature. The head of f is occasionally slightly flattened.
g is Caroline with a closed bowl, and is thus eight-shaped, one of Ker's (1957) defining characteristics of s. xiimed hands. From its top bow, it often ligatures with the following letter.
h is Caroline.
p has a well-defined horizontal foot (again, typical of mid-twelfth-century hands).
r is consistently Caroline, with a curved serif.
s is Caroline, with a determined onset stroke. Its head is occasionally slightly flattened.
The cross-bar of the t is often pierced by the stem, a feature seen in mid-twelfth-century script.
þ has a large bowl, and a descender that is slightly short in relation to the rest of the graph.
The ascender of ð is higher than other ascenders, and the cross-bar curves up on the right.
ƿ has a large pointed bowl, and short, straight descender.
y is rounded, sits just on the line, or slightly below, and is consistently dotted in the middle of the v-shaped limbs.
ascenders end in oblique serif rising from the left to the right or have a wedge.
descenders are generally short and straight, with the exception of p, which has a straight foot across the descender. Occasionally, descenders curve gently to the left.
Punctuation in the form of a semicolon at the end of a sentence occurs regularly up to p. 19, but seldom after that.
The punctus is frequently used, and sits on the line.
hyphens are used throughout at line ends, and at placed at a slight angle.
Abbreviation marks are curved at the right, ending in a blob.
The abbreviation for that consists of a þ with the abbreviation mark to the right of the ascender.
Men is abbreviated to M (often uncial in shape) with a macron above it.
leofestan is usually abbreviated simply to l with a line through it.
Drihten is abbreviated with a macron over the t.
The ˥ is formed with a 45º angle between headstroke and descender, and usually with a pronounced upward tick to the left of the headstroke.The tail tends to curve just below the line to the left.
The st ligature is used but not consistently.
The or ligature where the r is 2-shaped is used but not consistently.

The Litterae Notabiliores are closely related to those seen in other Worcester manuscripts of this date, and slightly earlier. They are red, pen-drawn, and display little roundels in the leg or the bowl.

handNote.p: There are several layers of glosses by the Tremulous Hand. s. xiii1

musicNotation.p: Pages 96-8 are blank, except for scribbles in the Tremulous Hand and some musical notes.

decoDesc.decoNote: Initials and titles in red. Titles in rustic capitals or minuscules.

additions.p: The collect Deus qui dedisti legem Moisi in summitate montis Sinay. et illic / per angelum tuum corpus Katerine uirginis. mirabiliter / collocasti. tribue quesumus. ut eius meritis et intercessione ad montem qui Cristus est ualeamus peruenire. and antiphon Ecce crucem domini. fugite partes aduerse de tribu Juda radix David. Alleluia. were added slightly later in s. xii in the five lines remaining blank on p. 395. A note in Thomas Barlow's hand identifies the collect with that in Roman and Sarum service-books for 25th November, St. Katherine's day, specifically concerning her reception by angels. The antiphon was used as an exorcism or healing formula. It is interesting to note this addition for St. Katherine in a manuscript associated with the region that produced the early thireenth-century manuscript, Oxford, Bodleian Library, Bodley 34, containing the Katherine-Group of Saints' lives and other texts.

binding.p: Bound in s. xvii/xviii uniformly with MS. Hatton 115. The rust-mark from a nail which held the strap of an earlier binding in position shows on pp. 391-402.

accMat.p: Pages 399-402 are two waste leaves, a bifolium of a copy of a Summa of the Decretum of Gratian, s. xiiex, used as a pastedown and flyleaf.

history.origin:
12th century, second quarter, with added glosses, 13th century, first half England, west, almost certainly Worcester, Benedictine cathedral priory of St Mary the Virgin
Written in the West of England, almost certainly at Worcester. Whilst the manuscript shows characteristics common with manuscripts produced at Worcester, McIntyre 1978 points out that the style is regional, not just belonging to a single scriptorium (pp. 36-37). It must be borne in mind, however, that there are also many shared features with manuscripts produced in other centres in the West of England (Treharne 2000, p. 27).
history.provenance: At Worcester Priory in the first half of the thirteenth century, as it was glossed by the Tremulous Hand. Remained there until at least 1622, as it is mentioned in Young's catalogue.
Belonged to Christopher, Lord Hatton in 1644.
history.acquisition: Given to the Bodleian by Hatton's son in 1675. Subsequently lent to Dr Thomas Marshall and by him to Franciscus Junius and returned to the Bodleian as part of the Junius collection after his death in 1678. Former shelfmark MS. Junius 24.

recordHist.source: Adapted (March 2022) from description created for The Production and Use of English Manuscripts 1060 to 1220 by Elaine Treharne with the assistance of Hollie Morgan and George Younge (2010; 2013). Previously described in the Summary Catalogue. Summary Catalogue, Vol. 2 Part 2, p. 969
